definition: a smashing blow or attack
a hard overhand stroke (as in tennis or badminton)
the action or sound of smashing
utter collapse : ruin
a striking success
to break or crush by violence
to drive or throw violently especially with a shattering or battering effect
to hit violently : batter
to hit (something, such as a tennis ball) with a hard overhand stroke
to drive (a ball) with a forceful stroke
to destroy utterly : wreck

to move or become propelled with violence or crashing effect                                      
             
             smashed into a tree
to become wrecked
to go to pieces suddenly under collision or pressure

being a smash : outstanding                                      
             
             a smash hit
someone or something that is very successful or popular
the sound made when something hits a surface very violently
a hard downward hit in tennis or other games
to break (something) into many pieces : to shatter or destroy (something)
to hit (something) violently and very hard
to hit (a ball) downward and very hard in tennis and other games
a violent blow

the action or sound of shattering or hitting violently                                      
             
             He broke the plate with a smash.

a striking success                                      
             
             The show was a smash.

to break in pieces : shatter                                      
             
             She smashed the dishes.

to hit or move violently                                      
             
             He smashed a ball over the fence.

to destroy completely                                      
             
             Our best swimmer smashed the state record.
in: smashed into a tree
a smash hit
The new movie is a smash.
She was a smash at the party.
His new song promises to be a smash hit.
The vase fell to the ground with a loud smash.
She hit an overhand smash that won the match.

The ball smashed the window.
The vase fell and smashed to pieces.
He smashed into the wall.
She smashed the ball deep into the opposite corner.
He broke the plate with a smash.
The show was a smash.
She smashed the dishes.
He smashed a ball over the fence.
Our best swimmer smashed the state record.
He smashed the car.

definition: to break something noisily into many pieces by dropping or hitting it with a lot of force
to break noisily into many pieces
to hit something against an object or surface with a lot of force, causing injury or damage
to hit against an object or surface with a lot of force, causing injury or damage
to completely destroy or defeat something such as an organization
to hit a ball very hard
in tennis, to hit a ball that is above your head downwards and very hard
to succeed completely in doing something
in: Someone had smashed a window.
The bottle slipped and smashed to pieces on the floor.
He fell and smashed his head on the pavement.
waves smashed over the boat
Are you smashing work or is it smashing you?
Good luck with the training and I hope you smash it in Rio!
smash a record

definition: to cause something to break noisily into a lot of small pieces:
to cause something to move with great force against something hard, usually causing damage or injury:
in tennis or volleyball, to hit the ball down towards the ground quickly and forcefully
to defeat someone or to destroy something completely:
to do much better than the best or fastest result recorded previously:
the sound of something being smashed:
the sound of something smashing against something:
a road or train accident
in tennis or volleyball, a powerful downward hit that sends the ball forcefully over the net
an extremely popular and successful song, play, or film:
to break into small pieces, esp. by hitting or throwing:
to hit or move with force against something hard, usually causing damage or injury:
to defeat or destroy completely:
the sound of something breaking into small pieces:
a forcefully hit ball:
